title: 106_hr1786
content: The "Education for the 21st Century (E-21) Act" aims to utilize computer hardware in schools to enhance student achievement and prepare them for the modern workplace. Congress finds that establishing computer literacy programs for students is crucial for their advanced education and future employment opportunities in the 21st century. Computer skills enhance critical thinking, communication, and information gathering, complementing core subjects like reading and mathematics. Research shows that students benefit from using computers for simulations and applications in their studies. Despite schools acquiring modern computer hardware, the importance of computer literacy programs remains paramount. The importance of teachers being trained in the latest educational software applications is highlighted for schools to fully benefit from computer-based learning. A study by the Educational Testing Service showed that students performed better when their teachers received computer training. Schools providing professional development in computers experienced higher staff morale and lower absenteeism rates. Exciting educational technology applications are being developed by both commercial software companies and students, with the potential to benefit elementary and secondary schools. The Computer Literacy Challenge is highlighted as a key initiative to enhance teachers' training in educational software applications for schools to benefit from computer-based learning. The Secretary of Education can award grants to States prioritizing technology literacy for middle school graduates. Grants are for teacher training in technology, focusing on preparing teachers to become technology leaders and train others. States must encourage matching funds for teacher training. Authorization of Appropriations: $30,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004 is authorized to enhance teacher training in technology for middle school graduates to ensure computer literacy. SEC. 5. HIGH-QUALITY EDUCATIONAL SOFTWARE FOR ALL SCHOOLS. The Secretary of Education can award grants to students, faculty, developers, and experts for creating educational software and websites. Outstanding projects will be recognized with certificates signed by the President and Secretary. The Secretary of Education can award grants for developing educational software and websites focusing on core curriculum areas. Priority is given to mathematics, science, reading in the first year, and in the following years, social studies, humanities, and arts are included. Official judges will be designated by the Secretary. The Secretary will designate official judges to recognize educational software and websites. Educational software can be downloaded for free from the Department of Education's website, while websites will be accessible to all users. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004 for this program.
